Here's what I'm seeing with inflation and savings right nowâ€”and why your emergency fund might actually be an erosion fund.

Most people don't know about M2. It's the total money supply in the economy: cash, checking accounts, savings, and short-term CDs. Add it all up and you're looking at $22.4 trillion. And it's growing fastâ€”about 5.7% in the past year alone.

Here's the issue nobody talks about:

If you're keeping significant cash in a standard savings account earning 0.5% while inflation runs 2.4%, you're not preserving wealth. You're losing it. Quietly. Relentlessly. About $1,200 per year in lost purchasing power for every $50,000 sitting idle.

The pandemic money surge (40% M2 growth in under 2 years) already hit us with 9.1% inflation in 2022. Today, money velocity is lowâ€”people are saving, not spending. But that dam could break. If spending accelerates while all this money remains in circulation, inflation pressures return.

What I'm telling clients:

â†’ Audit your cash position. More than 6 months of expenses in a low-yield account? You're going backward.

â†’ Explore high-yield savings accounts and Treasury I Bonds for funds you won't need immediately.

â†’ Stay informed. Watch CPI reports and Fed commentary. Knowledge is your best defense against gradual wealth erosion.

The economy isn't going to stop changing. Your strategy shouldn't either.

What's your approach to protecting cash from inflation? I'd love to hear what's working for youâ€”or what questions you have.
